thread.title: Krakouer, Jonas, Colquhuon, Moore dropped as Port Adelaide coach Ken Hinkley swings changes | The
thread.title_full: Krakouer, Jonas, Colquhuon, Moore dropped as Port Adelaide coach Ken Hinkley swings changes | The Advertiser

author: MICHELANGELO RUCCI CHIEF FOOTBALL WRITER
title: Krakouer, Jonas, Colquhuon, Moore dropped as Port Adelaide coach Ken Hinkley swings changes | The
text:
PORT Adelaide coach Ken Hinkley is shuffling - more so than shaking - the decks with four unforced changes as he strives to keep the Power’s listing AFL finals aspirations afloat at Adelaide Oval tomorrow night against the pacesetting Collingwood.
And the surprise outcast at selection was upgraded rookie Nathan Krakouer.
Hinkley is recasting his defence, both out of choice and necessity by regaining key defender Jackson Trengove and recalling Tom Clurey and Cam O’Shea.
They replace the full back Alipate Carlile (back soreness) and discarded pair Tom Jonas and Krakouer, who had worked on each side of the centre line in recent weeks.
Jonas is the major axing, but not surprising considering how the versatile defender has struggled to hold form or be effective in several match-ups while opposition teams have tested him in marking contests and against opportunist forwards.
But - after forecasting Jonas’ demotion in his morning press confence - Hinkley did not follow up with another big axing as external speculation put ruckman Matthew Lobbe, utility Justin Westhoff and defensive half-forward Angus Monfries in the firing line.
Rather, Hinkley cut inexperienced midfielders Andrew Moore and Sam Colquhuon who is on the comeback trail from a major knee injury. Colquhuon’s dumping ends a run of three games since he returned to the AFL.
Power midfield coach Michael Voss explained each of Krakouer and Colquhuon would get strong advice - and notes of challenge - after missing at selection.
“Krak needs to have consistency across the game - that is his challenge,” Voss said. “We know that when Krak has the ball in his hands, something happens. But we are looking for other things as well.
“Sam has certainly played well for the first couple of weeks - but he also has to work on some things. We also understand being out of the game for a while (with the knee injury) can do that (to a player’s form).”
Moore and Colquhuon are replaced by the equally inexperienced midfielder Karl Amon and speed-machine small forward Jake Neade.
COLLINGWOOD is unchanged as coach Nathan Buckley holds faith in a group that has pushed - but not beaten - AFL top-four measuring sticks, Fremantle in Perth and Hawthorn at the MCG, in the past fortnight.
The Power at 5-8 faces the challenge of winning at least eight of its remaining nine home-and-away games to qualify for the AFL final series in September for the third consecutive season under Hinkley.
Port Adelaide does have a strong record against Collingwood under Hinkley’s watch - two wins from three matches, including an elimination final at the MCG. The loss - in the last meeting in round 19 last season at the MCG - was by just six points.
Buckley expects the Power players - who take to the field for the first time since premiership assistant coach Phil Walsh died on Friday - to be galvanised amid their tragedy.
“One thing I can assure Ken Hinkley is that once he gets to the ground with his players and his coaches with a job to do, they will be galvanised towards that,” Buckley said with experience from leading the Magpies last Friday as the AFL world coped with Walsh’s death that day.
